newsitem.title: CZECH REPUBLIC: Czech PM says expected EU decision, will work hard.
newsitem.headline: Czech PM says expected EU decision, will work hard.

text.p: Czech Prime Minister Vaclav Klaus said on Wednesday a European Commission recommendation to begin EU membership talks with Prague had been expected and that his government was making intensive preparations.
"We are glad that it happened. I have to say we expected it would happen. We are preparing...intensively for the start of the negotiations," Klaus told a news conference.
He said he had not read the Commission's opinion in detail but, from the reports he had seen, it seemed to be "a satisfactory evaluation".
The Commission earlier on Wednesday recommended the European Union begin accession talks with five East European states, including the Czech Republic, and with Cyprus.
The EU ambassador to the Czech Republic, Joannes Ter Haar, told a news conference the commission's view was generally very positive. There were no acute problems despite some concerns.

The Czech Republic was long seen as in the forefront of reform in Eastern Europe but a worsening economic situation and political wobbles have taken some of the shine off its image with foreign investors.
Ter Haar said more needed to be done in the industrial sector including further restructuring, privatisation and streamlining. Corporate governance also must be improved.
He also said supervision of the capital markets needed to be enhanced and that there should be more bank privatisation.
"The prime objective must always be that the industrial sector of the Czech Republic be optimally competitive once the single market becomes available to it on membership," he said.

Many investors have complained about a lack of transparency in the capital markets, which have been hit by numerous scandals in recent months. They also say the lack of a developed capital market has slowed essential restructuring.
Ter Haar said a well-functioning civil service law was needed, as were improvements in the judicial system. There were too few judges and the courts worked too slowly.
One concern highlighted in the conclusion to the 104-page document concerned the Czechs' import deposit scheme, introduced in April to curb a yawning trade gap.
Under the scheme, importers have to deposit interest-free in banks 20 percent of the value of certain goods for 180 days.
"We consider it should be scrapped," said EU delegation official David Ringrose, adding the Commission believed it breached the Czechs' association agreement with the EU.
Ringrose said the Commission was going ahead with dispute settlement procedures. "This implies we consider the scheme should be withdrawn. If not we will move towards arbitration".
He added that the recent depreciation of the Czech crown, which was allowed to float freely on May 27 after a wave of speculative selling, made it simpler to withdraw the scheme.
"They have touched the most important things in quite an accurate way," said analyst Vladimir Kreidl of Patria Finance.

"The work that has to be done is enormous so the progress is only gradual but I think that in the end we will be able to adopt all the necessary legislation that is in force in the EU," he said, highlighting corporate governance, the financial and energy sectors as areas requiring more work.
But he also expressed concern that the Commission had identified deficiencies in Czech health and safety law. Such laws were sometimes inflexible in EU countries.
"This would not be a big improvement for the functioning of the Czech economy," he said.
